DataElement.preferredName: Demographic Patient United States Bureau of Census Occupation Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Code for the patient's usual occupation, using U.S. Census Bureau codes (2000 Census is preferable) according to coding procedures recommended for death certificates.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: statistical characterization of human populations (or segments of human populations broken down by age or sex or income etc.).

Concepts.definition: The statistical characterization of human populations or segments of human populations (e.g., characterization by age, sex, race, or income).

Property.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.:Crafts, trades, professions, or other means of earning a living.C0028811: Occupation

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.
The principal activity that a person does to earn money.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NAACCR Data Dictionary
ReferenceDocuments.description: North American Association of Central Cancer Registries, Standards for Cancer Registries, Volume II, Data Standards and Data Dictionary, Eleventh Edition, Version 11.1

ReferenceDocuments.name: Census Occupation Code Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: Use U.S. Census Bureau codes according to coding procedures recommended for death certificates.  This data item applies only to patients who are age 14 years or older at the time of diagnosis.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Codes Comment
ReferenceDocuments.description: For the 1990 Census codes, see Instructional Manual Part 19: Industry and Occupation Coding for Death Certificates, 1999, and related materials in the reference list, Chapter VI. A similar instruction manual for the 2000 Census codes has not been developed. Software for automated coding of occupation and industry is available from the Division of Safety Research, National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, CDC.
